awd_titl_txt: Conference: Support for Conferences and Mentoring of Women and Underrepresented Groups in Political Methodology
awd_abstract_narration:
Diverse voices and diverse methodological approaches are essential for solving the challenges facing society today. This project supports educational, training, and networking opportunities for members of under-represented groups to engage and give voice to these future and young scholars. First, we build a support-network and provide methodological education for a cohort of undergraduates, creating a potential pipeline of diversity into the field by recruiting women and students of color. Second, we provide explicit support for a women's conference in methodology, building a supportive community for women methodologists. Third, we provide explicit support for the field's annual national meeting to support the participation of women and students of color.  In this way, we are able to address the most critical weaknesses in the field of political methodology and provide meaningful growth and attention to each, in particular allowing relationships to build in ways that both diversify the field and allow for expansion into new communities of scholars.  


With rising interest worldwide in data science and measurement, the field of political methodology is increasingly central to the study of political science. This proposal supports multiple efforts by the Society for Political Methodology to engage and give voice to a diverse array of scholars. These efforts include (a) providing undergraduate students in underrepresented groups educational training in partnership with the ICPSR Summer Program in Quantitative Methods of Social Research, (b) supporting the Visions in Methodology Conference for women in political methodology, (c) supporting the attendance of women and students of color at the Society for Political Methodology Annual Meeting, and (d) fostering greater dialogue and data-sharing across constituent groups. By attending to each step in the pipeline, we maximize the chances that our efforts to meaningfully diversity the field will be successful.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Society for Political Methodology used NSF funding to create multiple pathways for diversifying the field of political methodology - the branch of political science focused on developing and applying advanced statistical methods to understand political phenomena. Through three main programs, this initiative has made significant progress in making the field more inclusive and accessible to traditionally underrepresented groups.

First, the project established an undergraduate pipeline program called the SPM Undergraduate Inclusivity & Expansion Fellowship. This program supported cohorts of 8 undergraduates from underrepresented groups each year to attend an intensive summer statistics program at the University of Michigan. Beyond just coursework, students received ongoing mentoring from leading scholars and hands-on research experience through paid research assistantships. This comprehensive approach helped students build both the technical skills and professional networks needed to succeed in quantitative political science.

Second, the project supported the Visions in Methodology (VIM) conference, an annual gathering specifically designed to promote and support women methodologists. Over the grant period, VIM consistently attracted over 100 applicants per year despite having space for only about 30 participants, demonstrating the strong demand for such focused mentoring and networking opportunities. The conference combined technical presentations with professional development sessions addressing challenges specific to women in the field. Survey data showed that participants rated VIM higher than other methodology conferences for its supportive environment and networking opportunities.

Third, the project enhanced diversity at the field's main annual conference (PolMeth) by providing travel funding for women and minority scholars. This support helped achieve historic levels of women's participation - reaching 37% of attendees, matching the proportion of women in the broader political science field. The conference implemented innovations like pre-conference sessions featuring women scholars' research and establishing formal codes of conduct to create a more inclusive environment.

The broader impacts of this work extend beyond just increasing numerical representation. The project has helped create sustainable networks and mentoring relationships that will continue supporting diversity in the field. Many past participants have gone on to take leadership roles in the Society and secure faculty positions at top institutions. For example, several women supported by the program now hold positions at schools like Harvard, Michigan, and UCLA, where they serve as role models and mentors for the next generation.

While the project made particular progress in supporting women's participation in political methodology, challenges remain in increasing racial and ethnic diversity. However, the established programs provide a strong foundation for continued work in this area. The project also adapted effectively to challenges like the COVID-19 pandemic by shifting to virtual formats when needed, which sometimes allowed for even broader participation.

This NSF investment has helped transform political methodology into a more inclusive field that benefits from diverse perspectives and talents. The multi-pronged approach - combining undergraduate training, focused mentoring through VIM, and broader conference support - has created lasting institutional changes that will continue promoting diversity in quantitative political science research. As data and statistical methods become increasingly central to understanding political phenomena, ensuring broad and diverse participation in political methodology is crucial for the field's future.
